content:
ronfouchier said
In the past all my accounts relied on pop3, but now of them changed to imap only, which now shows up like this: Is there a way for me to have just one inbox folder? If I choose View > Folders > Unified folders I get this:

You had used the "Global Inbox (Local Folders)" for your POP accounts before. This feature only works with POP accounts, not with IMAP accounts. To unify your IMAP accounts your only choice is "Unified Folders". This feature unifies ALL folders, not only the Inbox folders
creator: Mapenzi

content:
This is Wayne, the community manager for Thunderbird. This notification window is not malware. The only way to dismiss it is to click the “x” which is not a button, it is a window control.

If the notification appears again after having dismissed it previously, then we have a problem.

content:
The notification is designed not to persist after you dismiss it be clicking the X, which is standard for everything in the Thunderbird UI.

The descriptions of ESR and Release are at https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/choosing-thunderbird-release-channel

If you post a screen shot of the notification you are seeing then we can determine whether something is wrong with it and can fix it.

content:
Hi Thomas,

If you don't want to do this manually, you can try the Mail Merge addon, it's made for this exact scenario.

Just keep in mind not to send it all in one go, as most e-mail providers don't like sending mass mail for a good reason (neither they nor you would like to get flagged as spammers). Check your provider for rate limits.

Regards, Balázs

content:
Bonjour, Les cas comme le tien se multiplient ces derniers temps, les utilisateurs pensent qu'ils ont perdu des messages alors qu'en fait ils n'ont qu'activé - souvent sans d'en apercevoir - la "Barre de filtre rapide", ce qui peut changer l'affichage des messages dans la liste des messages à droite de la liste des comptes/dossiers. Le problème n'est donc pas celui d'une disparition ou d'une perte de messages mais celui du filtre rapide qu'on ne sait pas correctement utiliser ou qu'on a activé par mégarde.

Dans ma deuxième copie d'écran j'essaie d'expliquer ce problème d'affichage selon certaine critères. L'image montre la partie supérieure de ma fenêtre principale de Thunderbird avec un dossier "Courrier entrant" sélectionné. On voit que ce dossier contient 148 messages dont deux non lus. Dans la partie droite avec la liste des messages j'ai activé la Barre de filtre rapide et dans cette barre j'ai cliqué sur (activé) le bouton "Non lus"; ce qui veut dire n'afficher que les messages non lus de mon dossier Courrier entrant (Inbox)

Maintenant ouvre ton Thunderbird et vérifié si tu as activé le filtre rapide, peu importe selon quelle catégorie tu filtres. Si c'est la cas clique dessus pour le désactiver et normalement tous tes messages devraient être affichés dans la liste...
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Your Polish user interface doesn't facilitate my comprehension. What do you mean by "Grouped" ? I can't find any menu item "Grouped" but your screen shots let me think of the "Unified Folders" view.

If the Inbox folder of one of your accounts is not taken into account in the Unified Folders view you have to R-click on the unified Inbox folder and select "Properties" in the context menu. Or in Polish: R-click on Odebrane > Wlasciwosci which will open the Properties dialogue box (see pictures) In the Wlasciwosci dialogue box click on the Wybierz... button which will open a list with all accounts and folders in which you have can check the Inbox folder which has not been included in the Unified Inbox view . The same method can be applied to another incomplete unified folder such as Sent, Trash, ....etc.
creator: Mapenzi

creator: wsmwk

content:
This is how I've always done it. It preserves your whole existing setup:

1. Launch Thunderbird on the host PC

2. Go to Thunderbird menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information

3. Click the Application Basics > Profile Folder 'Open Folder' button

4. The profile folder will open; navigate three levels up to the Roaming folder

5. Close TB, then copy the Thunderbird folder to a flash drive

6. Go to the target PC's Roaming folder as instructed above and delete the Thunderbird folder

7. Paste the Thunderbird folder from the flash drive to the new PC

8. Launch Thunderbird
creator: siffemoz

content:
Thunderbird mail folders are in mbox format, but the name doesn't reflect that. The easiest way to backup is to backup the entire profile. Here are example steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media

To answer your question in detail, IMAP accounts are at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles\<profilename>\imapmail\<accountname> and have names such as input, input.msf, sent, sent.msf, where the msf files are disposable indexes and the mbox file is the associated input or sent or other file name.
creator: davidsk
